comment_text.dn11:1.2: This was the scene for some controversial discussions with Jains (MN 56, SN 42.8), and Sāriputta’s touching declaration of faith shortly before his passing (SN 47.12, DN 16:1.16.1, DN 28). It is probably the Pāvā (modern Pawapuri) at which Mahāvīra died according to the Jain tradition.
comment_text.dn11:1.3: Kevaḍḍha is mentioned only here. Manuscripts spell his name variously as Kevaddha or Kevaṭṭa (“fisherman”). The Chinese form 堅固 means “sturdy” (from dṛḍha) and thus supports Kevaḍḍha.
comment_text.dn11:1.5: I have been asked to do the same thing for the same reason.
comment_text.dn11:1.9: In fact it is forbidden in Kd 15:8.2.23.
comment_text.dn11:2.2: The reading dhaṁsemi is dubious. An old Burmese manuscript has the reading dhammaṁ desemi, which echoes the Buddha just above. Note too that Kevaḍḍha urges the Buddha to “direct” the monks (samādisatu, from the same root as desemi). I think the tension is deliberate: Kevaḍḍha says he isn’t telling the Buddha how to teach, but he absolutely is. Other readings convey the sense “attack, insult”, but this seems out of place.
comment_text.dn11:3.8: As noted previously, the basic sense of pāṭihāriya is “demonstration”, and as the context here shows, it may or may not involve a “demonstration of wonders” i.e. a “miracle”.
comment_text.dn11:3.10: These three are mentioned frequently in the suttas. Only the last is endorsed by the Buddha, as it leads to genuine growth.
comment_text.dn11:5.1: Note how a skeptical mindset sticks closer to the truth.
comment_text.dn11:5.2: “Spell” is vijjā (Sanskrit vidyā, “(potent) knowledge”, cf. English “wicca”, “wizard”, “witch”). The commentary says it was practiced by the seers of Gandhāra (north-west Pakistan). Jain tradition also knows a Gandhārī mantra, but attribute it to certain vidyādhara deities. Sanskrit tradition similarly knows of a vidyādevī (“lore goddess”) named Gandhārī. Gandhāra was an ancient land of learning, and a convenient location for exotic magics.
comment_text.dn11:5.7: These feats that have nothing to do with spiritual growth, hence they may be produced or perhaps faked by a variety of means.
comment_text.dn11:6.1: “Revealing” is ādesana, from root dis “to indicate, show, or point”.
comment_text.dn11:6.2: The Pali terms here are citta, cetasika, vitakka, and vicāra.
comment_text.dn11:6.3: Here we have mano (twice) and citta.
comment_text.dn11:7.2: From maṇi, “gem”. Magical gems are a common feature of Indian storytelling. Buddhist stories often feature the “wish-granting gem” (cintāmaṇi), which according to the commentary is meant here.
comment_text.dn11:67.3: This story is presented as an actual event, but is phrased like a fable.
comment_text.dn11:67.4: The question is about meditation, not the annihilation of the material world. The first four jhānas are based on the “subtle form” (sukhumarūpa) that manifests as light in deep meditation. He is asking how to go beyond this to the formless attainments.
comment_text.dn11:68.1: The mendicant has already well developed the jhānas. | “Controlling the body as far as the Brahmā realm” is one of the “demonstrations of psychic power” listed above.
comment_text.dn11:68.2: The “gods of the Four Great Kings” are deities born in a realm subject to the overlords known as the Four Great Kings. These deities inhabit the lowest of the celestial realms.
comment_text.dn11:68.7: These are powerful spirits who guard the four quarters. In AN 8.36 it is explained that they, like the other leading gods mentioned below, achieved their station due to their greater generosity and morality.
comment_text.dn11:69.6: The “thirty-three” enjoy refined sensual delights. The number is a reduplication of the trinity. In Buddhist texts they are not enumerated, but Yājñavalkya reckons them as eight Vasus, eleven Rudras, twelve Ādityas, plus Indra and Prajāpati (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.9.2). The final pair are elsewhere said to be Dyaus (“Heaven” = Zeus) and Pṛthivī (“Earth”), or the twin Aśvins.
comment_text.dn11:70.6: Conventionally known as “lord of gods”, but in fact the ruler only of the relatively lowly realm of the thirty-three. He is Vedic Indra, heroic slayer of the dragon Vṛtra, and is the most personally known god in the Pali Canon.
comment_text.dn11:72.1: Gods in this realm (spelled yāma, “of Yama”) are subjects of the god of the dead, Yama.
comment_text.dn11:80.5: The previous deities achieved their station by mere morality and generosity, not by jhāna. The gods of Brahmā’s Host practiced the first jhāna, but they do not know what lies beyond.
comment_text.dn11:80.7: The same passage appears in DN 1:2.5.2, where it also had a satirical tone, poking fun at the pomposity of religious titles.
comment_text.dn11:80.8: Even Brahmā’s community are not confident.
comment_text.dn11:80.12: This passage may be one of the sources for the later use of nimitta to mean the appearance of light that signifies the approach of jhāna.
comment_text.dn11:81.5: He puffs his own chest, but like the ascetic teachers of DN 2, he does not answer the question.
comment_text.dn11:82.2: He addresses Brahmā with āvuso. This is often translated as “friend”, but the root is āyu (“age”) and it is respectful not familiar.
comment_text.dn11:83.1: Rather than trying to engage with Brahmā’s agenda, he keeps restating his question. This is a skillful way of curbing narcissism.
comment_text.dn11:83.6: Brahmā is embarrassed to reveal his ignorance. Perhaps a satire of Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.2.13, where Yājñavalkya takes Jāratkārava Ārtabhāga by the hand and leads him aside for a secret discussion.
comment_text.dn11:83.9: At least he is honest about his lack of knowledge, even if not publicly.
comment_text.dn11:85.11: The first pair of couplets rephrase the question about where the (absorptions based on) material form cease. This couplet is also found at SN 1.27:2.1, Ud 1.10:14.1. | A gādha is a “ford” across a river (Rig Veda 7.60.7, 7.97.8, 10.106.9; Gopatha Brāhmaṇa 1.5.2a), a safe path on which one has a “footing” to cross the water. In this verse, the verb form gādhati means to be “established” (patiṭṭhita) like a seed in soil, or a beam of light on a floor, or consciousness in name and form.
comment_text.dn11:85.12: The verse is syntactically ambiguous, as there are three couplets, each with the question-word kattha, but only two verbs. I take the first pair of couplets as a distinct verse, with the verb gādhati acting as a “lamp” illuminating both the first and second couplets. These are also unified in that they deal only with material qualities.
comment_text.dn11:85.13: A similar list of descriptors elsewhere describes things that are not stolen (Snp 3.9:45.1) or the kinds of sentient beings (Snp 1.8:4.3). These are aspects of how “form” manifests in desirable or undesirable ways.
comment_text.dn11:85.14: Four terms in this verse are identical with the first four terms in Yājñavalkya’s description of the immutable Brahman as “neither coarse nor fine, neither short nor long” at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.8.8.
comment_text.dn11:85.15: This final couplet is distinguished in having a different verb (“cease”) and in including mental qualities (nāma). It therefore appears there are two questions with two answers.
comment_text.dn11:85.18: This couplet is spoken by Baka the Divinity at MN 49:25.1, so it was probably a free-floating couplet illustrating the Upaniṣadic theory of the Self as infinite consciousness. I think the Buddha is quoting Brahmā here in order to contrast with his own teaching of the cessation of consciousness, to emphasize that even this most sublime form of consciousness will cease. | “Where no form appears” (anidassanaṁ) here is a synonym for “formless” (see eg. MN 21:14.8, “space is formless and invisible”, ākāso arūpī anidassano). Normally the colors and images seen in the “form” absorptions are described as “appearing” (eg. DN 16:3.29.1), so this indicates a formless attainment.
comment_text.dn11:85.19: “Infinite” (ananta) is the direct qualifier of “consciousness”, but in the Pali it is shifted to the next line to fit the meter. It indicates the second of the formless attainments. Yājñavalkya describes consciousness as infinite in the famous passage at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.12. | Pabhaṁ means “luminous”, as with the deities that are “self-luminous” (sayaṁpabhā, DN 27:10.3). This echoes descriptions of the Divinity of consciousness as “radiant” (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 5.6.1, Chāndogya Upaniṣad 3.14.2) | Sabbato pabhaṁ (“luminous all-round”) is synonymous with pariyodāta (“bright”, literally “white all over”), a stock descriptor of the mind of fourth jhāna, on which the formless states are based.
comment_text.dn11:85.20: The division of these ten lines is not obvious. Since the previous couplet appears to be an independent saying, I take the remaining eight lines as two four-line verses. This couplet, too, appears as the first two lines of a six-line verse, with the initial yattha rather than ettha (SN 1.27:2.1).
comment_text.dn11:85.21: The verb “has no footing” applies to both the former and subsequent couplet.
comment_text.dn11:85.24: These lines also at Snp 5.2:6.6, with initial yattha instead of ettha.
comment_text.dn11:85.26: According to dependent origination, when consciousness ceases, name and form cease, and with it the manifestation of all things desirable and undesirable in the world.
comment_text.dn11:85.27: Throughout, take the locative ettha as locative of reference, as in similar constructions at eg. SN 1.30. The point is that when the Buddha is speaking of the cessation of consciousness, he is speaking specifically of the “infinite consciousness” of the Upaniṣads: that is what ceases.

root_text.dn11:78.3: “yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū”’ti.
root_text.dn11:79.1: Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu yena vasavattī devaputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā vasavattiṁ devaputtaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn11:79.2: ‘kattha nu kho, āvuso, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti?
root_text.dn11:79.3: Evaṁ vutte, kevaṭṭa, vasavattī devaputto taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn11:79.5: “yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū”ti.
root_text.dn11:79.6: Atthi kho, bhikkhu, brahmakāyikā nāma devā amhehi abhikkantatarā ca paṇītatarā ca.
root_text.dn11:79.8: “yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū”’ti.
root_text.dn11:80.1: Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu tathārūpaṁ samādhiṁ samāpajji, yathāsamāhite citte brahmayāniyo maggo pāturahosi.
root_text.dn11:80.2: Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu yena brahmakāyikā devā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā brahmakāyike deve etadavoca:
root_text.dn11:80.3: ‘kattha nu kho, āvuso, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti?
root_text.dn11:80.4: Evaṁ vutte, kevaṭṭa, brahmakāyikā devā taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.dn11:80.6: “yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū”ti.
root_text.dn11:80.7: Atthi kho, bhikkhu, brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṁ amhehi abhikkantataro ca paṇītataro ca.
root_text.dn11:80.9: “yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū”’ti.
root_text.dn11:80.11: ‘Mayampi kho, bhikkhu, na jānāma, yattha vā brahmā yena vā brahmā yahiṁ vā brahmā;
root_text.dn11:80.12: api ca, bhikkhu, yathā nimittā dissanti, āloko sañjāyati, obhāso pātubhavati, brahmā pātubhavissati, brahmuno hetaṁ pubbanimittaṁ pātubhāvāya, yadidaṁ āloko sañjāyati, obhāso pātubhavatī’ti.
root_text.dn11:81.1: Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, mahābrahmā nacirasseva pāturahosi.
root_text.dn11:81.2: Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu yena so mahābrahmā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṁ mahābrahmānaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn11:81.3: ‘kattha nu kho, āvuso, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti?
root_text.dn11:81.4: Evaṁ vutte, kevaṭṭa, so mahābrahmā taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn11:81.5: ‘ahamasmi, bhikkhu, brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānan’ti.
root_text.dn11:82.1: Dutiyampi kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu taṁ mahābrahmānaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn11:82.3: “tvamasi brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānan”ti.
root_text.dn11:82.4: Evañca kho ahaṁ taṁ, āvuso, pucchāmi:
root_text.dn11:82.5: “kattha nu kho, āvuso, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū”’ti?
root_text.dn11:82.6: Dutiyampi kho so, kevaṭṭa, mahābrahmā taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn11:82.7: ‘ahamasmi, bhikkhu, brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānan’ti.
root_text.dn11:83.1: Tatiyampi kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu taṁ mahābrahmānaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn11:83.3: “tvamasi brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānan”ti.
root_text.dn11:83.4: Evañca kho ahaṁ taṁ, āvuso, pucchāmi:
root_text.dn11:83.5: “kattha nu kho, āvuso, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū”’ti?
root_text.dn11:83.6: Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, mahābrahmā taṁ bhikkhuṁ bāhāyaṁ gahetvā ekamantaṁ apanetvā taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn11:83.7: ‘ime kho maṁ, bhikkhu, brahmakāyikā devā evaṁ jānanti, “natthi kiñci brahmuno aññātaṁ, natthi kiñci brahmuno adiṭṭhaṁ, natthi kiñci brahmuno aviditaṁ, natthi kiñci brahmuno asacchikatan”ti.
root_text.dn11:83.9: Ahampi kho, bhikkhu, na jānāmi yatthime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātūti.
root_text.dn11:83.10: Tasmātiha, bhikkhu, tuyhevetaṁ dukkaṭaṁ, tuyhevetaṁ aparaddhaṁ, yaṁ tvaṁ taṁ bhagavantaṁ atidhāvitvā bahiddhā pariyeṭṭhiṁ āpajjasi imassa pañhassa veyyākaraṇāya.
root_text.dn11:83.11: Gaccha tvaṁ, bhikkhu, tameva bhagavantaṁ upasaṅkamitvā imaṁ pañhaṁ puccha, yathā ca te bhagavā byākaroti, tathā naṁ dhāreyyāsī’ti.
root_text.dn11:84.1: Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṁ vā bāhaṁ pasāreyya, pasāritaṁ vā bāhaṁ samiñjeyya; evameva brahmaloke antarahito mama purato pāturahosi.
root_text.dn11:84.2: Atha kho so, kevaṭṭa, bhikkhu maṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi, ekamantaṁ nisinno kho, kevaṭṭa, so bhikkhu maṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn11:84.3: ‘kattha nu kho, bhante, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti?
root_text.dn11:85.1: Evaṁ vutte, ahaṁ, kevaṭṭa, taṁ bhikkhuṁ etadavocaṁ—
root_text.dn11:85.2: bhūtapubbaṁ, bhikkhu, sāmuddikā vāṇijā tīradassiṁ sakuṇaṁ gahetvā nāvāya samuddaṁ ajjhogāhanti.
root_text.dn11:85.3: Te atīradakkhiniyā nāvāya tīradassiṁ sakuṇaṁ muñcanti.
root_text.dn11:85.4: So gacchateva puratthimaṁ disaṁ, gacchati dakkhiṇaṁ disaṁ, gacchati pacchimaṁ disaṁ, gacchati uttaraṁ disaṁ, gacchati uddhaṁ disaṁ, gacchati anudisaṁ.
root_text.dn11:85.5: Sace so samantā tīraṁ passati, tathāgatakova hoti.
root_text.dn11:85.6: Sace pana so samantā tīraṁ na passati, tameva nāvaṁ paccāgacchati.
root_text.dn11:85.7: Evameva kho tvaṁ, bhikkhu, yato yāva brahmalokā pariyesamāno imassa pañhassa veyyākaraṇaṁ nājjhagā, atha mamaññeva santike paccāgato.
root_text.dn11:85.8: Na kho eso, bhikkhu, pañho evaṁ pucchitabbo:
root_text.dn11:85.9: ‘kattha nu kho, bhante, ime cattāro mahābhūtā aparisesā nirujjhanti, seyyathidaṁ—pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti?
root_text.dn11:85.10: Evañca kho eso, bhikkhu, pañho pucchitabbo:
root_text.dn11:85.29: Attamano kevaṭṭo gahapatiputto bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.dn11:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Nāḷandā in Pāvārika’s mango grove.
translation_text.dn11:1.3: Then the householder Kevaḍḍha went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.dn11:1.4: “Sir, this Nāḷandā is successful and prosperous, populous, full of people.
translation_text.dn11:1.5: Please direct a mendicant to perform a superhuman demonstration of psychic power.
translation_text.dn11:1.6: Then Nāḷandā will become even more devoted to the Buddha!”
translation_text.dn11:1.7: When he said this, the Buddha said,
translation_text.dn11:1.8: “Kevaḍḍha, I do not teach Dhamma to the mendicants like this:
translation_text.dn11:1.9: ‘Come now, mendicants, perform a superhuman demonstration of psychic power for the white-clothed laypeople.’”
translation_text.dn11:2.1: For a second time, Kevaḍḍha made the same request,
translation_text.dn11:2.2: “Sir, I am not teaching you the Dhamma,
translation_text.dn11:2.4: ‘Sir, this Nāḷandā is successful and prosperous, populous, full of people.
translation_text.dn11:2.5: Please direct a mendicant to perform a superhuman demonstration of psychic power.
translation_text.dn11:2.6: Then Nāḷandā will become even more devoted to the Buddha!’”
translation_text.dn11:2.7: But for a second time, the Buddha gave the same answer.
translation_text.dn11:3.1: For a third time, Kevaḍḍha made the same request,
translation_text.dn11:3.6: at which the Buddha said the following.
translation_text.dn11:3.8: “Kevaḍḍha, there are three kinds of demonstration, which I declare having realized them with my own insight.
translation_text.dn11:3.10: The demonstration of psychic power, the demonstration of revealing, and the demonstration of instruction.
translation_text.dn11:4.1: And what is the demonstration of psychic power?
translation_text.dn11:4.2: It’s a mendicant who wields the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again; materializing and dematerializing; going unobstructed through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.
translation_text.dn11:4.3: Someone with faith and confidence sees that mendicant performing those superhuman feats.
translation_text.dn11:4.4: They tell someone else who lacks faith and confidence:
translation_text.dn11:4.5: ‘Oh lord, how incredible, how amazing! The ascetic has such psychic power and might!
translation_text.dn11:4.6: I saw him myself, performing all these superhuman feats!’
translation_text.dn11:5.1: But the one lacking faith and confidence would say to them:
translation_text.dn11:5.3: Using that a mendicant can perform such superhuman feats.’
translation_text.dn11:5.5: Wouldn’t someone lacking faith speak like that?”
translation_text.dn11:5.7: “Seeing this drawback in psychic power, I’m horrified, repelled, and disgusted by demonstrations of psychic power.
translation_text.dn11:6.1: And what is the demonstration of revealing?
translation_text.dn11:6.2: It’s when a mendicant reveals the mind, mentality, thoughts, and reflections of other beings and individuals:
translation_text.dn11:6.3: ‘This is what you’re thinking, such is your thought, and thus is your state of mind.’
translation_text.dn11:6.4: Someone with faith and confidence sees that mendicant revealing another individual’s thoughts.
translation_text.dn11:6.6: They tell someone else who lacks faith and confidence:
translation_text.dn11:6.7: ‘Oh lord, how incredible, how amazing! The ascetic has such psychic power and might!
translation_text.dn11:6.8: I saw him myself, revealing the thoughts of another individual!’
translation_text.dn11:7.1: But the one lacking faith and confidence would say to them:
translation_text.dn11:7.3: Using that a mendicant can reveal another individual’s thoughts.’
translation_text.dn11:7.6: Wouldn’t someone lacking faith speak like that?”
translation_text.dn11:7.8: “Seeing this drawback in revealing, I’m horrified, repelled, and disgusted by demonstrations of revealing.
translation_text.dn11:8.1: And what is the demonstration of instruction?
translation_text.dn11:8.2: It’s when a mendicant instructs others like this:
translation_text.dn11:8.3: ‘Think like this, not like that. Focus your mind like this, not like that. Give up this, and live having achieved that.’
translation_text.dn11:8.4: This is called the demonstration of instruction.
translation_text.dn11:9-66.1: Furthermore, a Realized One arises in the world …
translation_text.dn11:9-66.2: That’s how a mendicant is accomplished in ethics. …
translation_text.dn11:9-66.3: They enter and remain in the first absorption …
translation_text.dn11:9-66.4: This is called the demonstration of instruction.
translation_text.dn11:9-66.5: They enter and remain in the second absorption …
translation_text.dn11:9-66.8: This too is called the demonstration of instruction.
translation_text.dn11:9-66.9: They project and extend the mind toward knowledge and vision …
translation_text.dn11:9-66.10: This too is called the demonstration of instruction.
translation_text.dn11:9-66.11: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.dn11:9-66.12: This too is called the demonstration of instruction.
translation_text.dn11:67.1: These, Kevaḍḍha, are the three kinds of demonstration, which I declare having realized them with my own insight.
translation_text.dn11:67.2.0: 4. On the Mendicant in Search of the Cessation of Being
translation_text.dn11:67.3: Once upon a time, Kevaḍḍha, a mendicant in this very Saṅgha had the following thought,
translation_text.dn11:67.4: ‘Where do these four principal states cease without anything left over, namely, the elements of earth, water, fire, and air?’
translation_text.dn11:68.1: Then that mendicant attained a state of immersion such that a path to the gods appeared.
translation_text.dn11:68.2: Then he approached the gods of the four great kings and said,
translation_text.dn11:68.3: ‘Reverends, where do these four principal states cease without anything left over, namely, the elements of earth, water, fire, and air?’
translation_text.dn11:68.4: When he said this, those gods said to him,
translation_text.dn11:68.5: ‘Mendicant, we too do not know this.
translation_text.dn11:68.7: But the four great kings are our superiors.
translation_text.dn11:69.1: Then he approached the four great kings and asked the same question.
translation_text.dn11:69.3: But they also said to him,
translation_text.dn11:69.4: ‘Mendicant, we too do not know this.
translation_text.dn11:69.6: But the gods of the thirty-three …
translation_text.dn11:76.1: the gods who love to create …
translation_text.dn11:77.2: the gods who control the creation of others …
translation_text.dn11:79.6: the gods of the Divinity’s host are our superiors.
translation_text.dn11:80.1: Then that mendicant attained a state of immersion such that a path to divinity appeared.
translation_text.dn11:80.2: Then he approached the gods of the Divinity’s host and said,
translation_text.dn11:80.3: ‘Reverends, where do these four principal states cease without anything left over, namely, the elements of earth, water, fire, and air?’
translation_text.dn11:80.4: But they also said to him,
translation_text.dn11:80.5: ‘Mendicant, we too do not know this.
translation_text.dn11:80.7: But there is the Divinity, the Great Divinity, the Vanquisher, the Unvanquished, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, God Almighty, the Maker, the Creator, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born. He is our superior.
translation_text.dn11:80.10: ‘But reverends, where is that Divinity now?’
translation_text.dn11:80.11: ‘We also don’t know where he is or what way he lies.
translation_text.dn11:80.12: But by the signs that are seen—light arising and radiance appearing—we know that Divinity will appear. For this is the precursor for the appearance of the Divinity, namely light arising and radiance appearing.’
translation_text.dn11:81.1: Not long afterwards, the Great Divinity appeared.
translation_text.dn11:81.2: Then that mendicant approached the Great Divinity and said to him,
translation_text.dn11:81.3: ‘Reverend, where do these four principal states cease without anything left over, namely, the elements of earth, water, fire, and air?’
translation_text.dn11:81.4: The Great Divinity said to him,
translation_text.dn11:81.5: ‘I am the Divinity, the Great Divinity, the Vanquisher, the Unvanquished, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, God Almighty, the Maker, the Creator, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born.’
translation_text.dn11:82.1: For a second time, that mendicant said to the Great Divinity,
translation_text.dn11:82.2: ‘Reverend, I am not asking you whether you are
translation_text.dn11:82.3: the Divinity, the Great Divinity, the Vanquisher, the Unvanquished, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, God Almighty, the Maker, the Creator, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born.
translation_text.dn11:82.5: where these four principal states cease without anything left over.’
translation_text.dn11:82.6: For a second time, the Great Divinity said to him,
translation_text.dn11:82.7: ‘I am the Divinity, the Great Divinity, the Vanquisher, the Unvanquished, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, God Almighty, the Maker, the Creator, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born.’
translation_text.dn11:83.1: For a third time, that mendicant said to the Great Divinity,
translation_text.dn11:83.2: ‘Reverend, I am not asking you whether you are
translation_text.dn11:83.3: the Divinity, the Great Divinity, the Vanquisher, the Unvanquished, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, God Almighty, the Maker, the Creator, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born.
translation_text.dn11:83.5: where these four principal states cease without anything left over.’
translation_text.dn11:83.6: Then the Great Divinity took that mendicant by the arm, led him off to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.dn11:83.7: ‘Mendicant, these gods think that there is nothing at all that I don’t know and see and understand and realize.
translation_text.dn11:83.8: That’s why I didn’t answer in front of them.
translation_text.dn11:83.9: But I too do not know where these four principal states cease with nothing left over.
translation_text.dn11:83.10: Therefore, mendicant, the misdeed is yours alone, the mistake is yours alone, in that you passed over the Buddha and searched elsewhere for an answer to this question.
translation_text.dn11:83.11: Mendicant, go to the Buddha and ask him this question. You should remember it in line with his answer.’
translation_text.dn11:84.1: Then that mendicant, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from the realm of divinity and reappeared in front of me.
translation_text.dn11:84.2: Then he bowed, sat down to one side, and said to me,
translation_text.dn11:84.3: ‘Sir, where do these four principal states cease without anything left over, namely, the elements of earth, water, fire, and air?’
translation_text.dn11:85.0: 4.1. The Simile of the Land-Spotting Bird
translation_text.dn11:85.1: When he said this, I said to him:
translation_text.dn11:85.2: ‘Once upon a time, mendicant, some sea-merchants set sail for the ocean deeps, taking with them a land-spotting bird.
translation_text.dn11:85.3: When their ship was out of sight of land, they released the bird.
translation_text.dn11:85.4: It flew right away to the east, the west, the north, the south, upwards, and in-between.
translation_text.dn11:85.5: If it saw land on any side, it went there and stayed.
translation_text.dn11:85.6: But if it saw no land on any side it returned to the ship.
translation_text.dn11:85.7: In the same way, after failing to get an answer to this question even after searching as far as the realm of divinity, you’ve returned to me.
translation_text.dn11:85.8: Mendicant, this is not how the question should be asked:
translation_text.dn11:85.9: “Sir, where do these four principal states cease without anything left over, namely, the elements of earth, water, fire, and air?”
translation_text.dn11:85.10: This is how the question should be asked:
translation_text.dn11:85.12: fire and air have no footing;
translation_text.dn11:85.14: fine and coarse, beautiful and ugly?
translation_text.dn11:85.17: And the answer to that is:
translation_text.dn11:85.21: fire and air have no footing;
translation_text.dn11:85.23: fine and coarse, beautiful and ugly.
translation_text.dn11:85.27: they cease in reference to this.”’”
translation_text.dn11:85.28: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.dn11:85.29: Satisfied, the householder Kevaḍḍha approved what the Buddha said.

variant_text.dn11:85.5: tathāgatakova → tathā pakkantova (cck); tathāpakkanto va (sya1ed, sya2ed)
